definition: Capricorn is the sign of the goat and occurs on January 1st. (See previous discussions)
mnemonic: ['Capricorn – Cap and Coat (goat) and horn playing (corn)', 'January – Janitor', 'Goat – Goat', 'The goat\xa0in the cap and coat played the horn (Capricorn\xa0and goat) on stage but only the janitor was watching']

definition: Aquarius is the sign of the water bearer and occurs on 1st February
mnemonic: ['Aquarius – Aqua various', 'Water bearer – Water\xa0into beer', 'February – Fed\xa0into Brewery', 'Aqua makes various beers (Aquarius). Water is fed into a brewery (February) and the water is turned into beer (water bearer)']

definition: Pisces is the sign of the fish and occurs on the 1st March
mnemonic: ['Pisces – Pie', 'Fish – Fish', 'March – Marching', 'The fish marched around the pie']

definition: Aries is the sign of the ram and occurs on April 1st. To remember this link the following:
mnemonic: ['Aries – Air', 'Ram – Ram', 'April – A pill', '', 'The ram took a blue pill\xa0(April) and\xa0jumped crazily up in the air (Aries).']

definition: Taurus is the sign of the bull and occurs on May 1st. To remember this link to :
mnemonic: ['Taurus – Tore up stuff', 'Bull – Bull', 'May –\xa0Maypole', 'The bull tore up stuff so they tied him on the maypole.']
highlighted_text: ['Taurus – Tore up stuff', '–', 'Bull – Bull', '–', 'May –\xa0Maypole', '–', 'bull', 'tore up stuff', 'may']

definition: Gemini is the sign of twins and occurs on June 1st
mnemonic: ['Gemini – Gems', 'Twins – Twins', 'June – Dune', '', 'In June the twins always ski on their gem-encrusted\xa0skis down dunes']

definition: Cancer is the sign of the crab and occurs on July 1st
mnemonic: ['Cancer – Can', 'Crab – Crab', 'July – To lie in a hammock', '', 'To get away from the crab who seemed to crush everything including cans, he had to\xa0lie in his hammock.']
highlighted_text: ['Cancer – Can', '–', 'Crab – Crab', '–', 'July – To lie in a hammock', '–', '', 'crab', 'cans', 'to', 'lie', 'hammock.']

definition: Leo is the sign of the lion and occurs on the 1st of August.
mnemonic: ['Leo –\xa0The lion', 'Lion –\xa0Lion', 'August –\xa0All guests', 'Leo the lion produces all the gusts of wind that are produced in the world.']

definition: Virgo is the sign of the virgin and occurs on September 1st.
mnemonic: ['Virgo – Virgin goes', 'Virgin – Virgin Mary', 'September – Septic (tank) member', 'The\xa0Virgin Mary\xa0walks\xa0away\xa0(virgin goes)\xa0from the septic tank member.']

definition: Libra is the sign of the scales and occurs on October 1st. To remember this, link the following:
mnemonic: ['Libra – Library', 'Scales – Scales', 'October – Octopus', 'It was almost impossible to weigh the octopus on the scales while she was trying to read books from the library']

definition: Scorpio is the sign of the scorpion and occurs on November 1st.
mnemonic: ['Scorpio – Scorpion', 'Scorpion – Scorpion', 'November – Novel', 'The\xa0scorpion decided to write a novel about an adventure in a rainforest.']

definition: Sagittarius is the sign of the archer and occurs on December 1st.
mnemonic: ['Sagittarius – Sag', 'Archer – Archer', 'December – Christmas', 'She opened her Christmas\xa0present and had been given an archery set but the string\xa0was all saggy.']
['Protons (peas) are positively charged.', 'The pea (proton) is positive.']

definition: Neutrons (newts) are neutral and have no charge.
mnemonic: ['Neutrons (newts) are neutral and have no charge.', 'The newt (neutron) is a light brown neutral colour and has a neutral charge (zero charge).']
['Electrons (electronic robots) are negatively charged.', 'The electronic robots (electrons)\xa0are negative and have a negative charge.']

definition: The atomic number tells you how many protons the element has.
mnemonic: ['The atomic number is a tom cat with only a pea to eat (proton).']
images: ['https://mammothmemory.net/images/user/base/Chemistry/2. Atomic Structure/2.2.10 Atomic number memory aid (2).jpg']

definition: The mass number is the number of protons plus the number of neutrons in the atom. It is always the biggest number and is roughly double the atomic number.
mnemonic: ['The mass number is represented by a bull mastiff eating a bowl of peas (protons) and newts (neutrons). (I.e. all the live yummy bits, not electronic\xa0robots (electrons), because who wants to eat an electronic robot!)']
images: ['https://mammothmemory.net/images/user/base/Chemistry/2. Atomic Structure/2.2.11 Mass number memory aid (2).jpg']

definition: The periodic table shows the unique symbol of every element, together with its mass number and atomic number. For example, lithium (Li) has a mass number of 7 and an atomic number of 3
mnemonic: ['A bull mastiff (mass) dog is sitting on top of\xa0a tom (atomic) cat. The mass number is always the bigger\xa0number.']
images: ['https://mammothmemory.net/images/user/base/Chemistry/2. Atomic Structure/2.2.12 Mass and atomic numbers block.jpg', 'https://mammothmemory.net/images/user/base/Chemistry/2. Atomic Structure/2.2.13 Mass is always bigger memory aid.jpg']

word: The periodic table has no charge
images: ['https://mammothmemory.net/images/user/base/Chemistry/2. Atomic Structure/2.2.14 Periodic table has no charge image (2).jpg']

definition: THAT IS IT. The last 8 pages are the essential basics of Chemistry i.e.
images: ['https://mammothmemory.net/images/user/base/Chemistry/2. Atomic Structure/2.2.12 Mass and atomic numbers block.jpg']

definition: Protons and neutrons weigh the same, whereas electrons weigh very little (almost nothing)
mnemonic: ['Protons (peas) have a mass of one.', 'Neutrons (newts) weigh the same as protons (peas), so also have a mass of one.', 'On the other hand, electrons\xa0(electronic robots) weigh almost nothing whatsoever… they’re empty inside!']

definition: Hydrogen has a mass number of one and an atomic number of one.
All atoms of an element will have the same number of protons. However, atoms of the same element can sometimes have a different number of neutrons. These are called isotopes.
mnemonic: ['The newts (neutrons) are skating ‘on top’ of the ice (‘ice on top’ – isotope).']

definition: Some electrons are closer to the nucleus of an atom than others. Electrons actually orbit the nucleus in what are known as “shells”.
mnemonic: ['To help you remember that electrons are arranged in shells, imagine our electronic robot\xa0(electron) hatching out of a shell:']

definition: Valency is the number of bonds an atom can make with other atoms, usually based on the number of electrons in its outer shell.
mnemonic: ['To help you remember that valency is about an atom’s potential to bond, imagine a bride who’s told to lift her veil and see (valency) how many grooms want to bond with her.']

mnemonic: ['Ready! Steady! Accelerate-and-go! (accelerando) The two boys start pedalling their go-carts and gradually get quicker.']
['The adder, she goes (adagio) very slowly so we have to wait for her.']

definition: Fairly quickly (but not as quick as allegro)
mnemonic: ['Because there is no queue at the alley grotto (allegretto) you can see Santa fairly quickly.']
['The athlete had a leg grow (allegro) and cheerfully ran quickly to win the race.']
['I took my dog and auntie (andante) for a walk at a medium speed.']
["Tonight they proved you can't table lay (cantabile) while singing opera."]
['When the creche ends (crescendo) the noise gets gradually louder as children see their parents.']
["He'd dropped his cap - oh dear! (capo). It meant he had to repeat from the beginning."]
["The steward is worried they'll say no (dal segno), because they have to repeat from the sign and queue again tomorrow!"]
['The decrease in the noise after creche ended (decrescendo), as the parents drove away was a gradual decline but it was such a relief.']

definition: Gradually getting quieter and slowing down
mnemonic: ['The sound of the foghorn will dim in the end (diminuendo): as you speed away from the shore it will gradually get quieter. Now the noise is less he can gradually slow down too.']
highlighted_text: ['dim in', 'end', 'gradually get quieter. Now the noise is less he can gradually slow down too.', '.', 'Now the noise is less he can', 'down too.']

mnemonic: ['"That doll chair (dolce) would make such a sweet present for my daughter!"']
['The shark had a fin shaped like an A (fine) at the end of its tail.']
['The battle at the fort was a (forte) loud one. The fort had a large #forte\xa0above the drawbridge.']
["The forty sumo (fortissimo) wrestlers' shouts were very loud."]
['To complete the tattoo leg art (legato), he needed a smooth leg.']
['He was so leant over (lento) on his stick that he was very slow.']
['They met to sew (mezzo) exactly half way between their houses.']
['They met to sew (mezzo) exactly half way between their houses.', 'The battle at the fort was a (forte) loud one. The fort had a large #forte\xa0above the drawbridge.']
['Mezzo (M.) – Half', '(Pronounced met-soh)', 'They met to sew (mezzo) exactly half way between their houses.', "The tiny mouse played the piano so quietly so that she didn't wake anyone up."]
["The tiny mouse played the piano so quietly so that she didn't wake anyone up."]
['Will she pee on this sumo (pianissimo)? The baby is very quiet, but she is full of surprises!']
["Their Thursday night poker (poco) game was a little treat after a hard week's scavenging."]
['As Dad approached the rally on a tandem (rallentando) he got gradually slower.']
['The roadworkers re-tarred and do (ritardando) repairs on the road but got gradually slower as they become tired.']

definition: an immediate, or sudden, reduction in speed or tempo
mnemonic: ['Please believe that I have written you too (ritenuto) but the postal service strike may suddenly slow down my letter.', 'She had written a new song with her toes (ritenuto), but it took ages; writing like this suddenly reduces the speed you can write.']

definition: Each note detached or separated from each other
mnemonic: ['The stack of cards were oh (staccato) so high but then suddenly tumbled and the cards became detached.']

['Note: Tempo is the rate of speed of a musical piece indicated by directions (such as largo or allegro) and often by an exact metronome marking.', 'He was so naughty he lost his temper (tempo) all the time.', 'You could see she had a temper going. Oh (tempo) this was going to be bad. Mum was at the front door, scowling, folded arms and tapping her foot.']
['They were all banned from going near (Albania) the tyrannosaurus (Tirana).']

definition: Andorra's capital is Andorra la villa
mnemonic: ['The handle of the door (Andorra) was the reason the house was called "Hand on the Door Villa" (Andorra la villa).']
['The ostrich bit his ear (Austria) and gave him a V-sign to show he was his enemy (Vienna).']
['Ringing the bell was a ruse (Belarus); it called the minks (Minsk) out of the water and the hunters shot them.']
['The bell is covered in jam (Belgium) and has a brussel\xa0(Brussels) sprout for a clapper.']

definition: Bosnia and Herzegovina's capital is Sarajevo
mnemonic: ["The boss is near and the bodyguards will stop anyone who wants to hurt their guv'nor (Bosnia and Herzegovina). They will be sorry if a vole (Sarajevo) attacks her."]
['The bull glared (Bulgaria) at her but she just sat on the sofa with no fear (Sofia).']
["The crow ate ya (Croatia): with it's lizard tongue it could zap and grab you (Zagreb)."]
["She didn't use the cider press (Cyprus), she pressed the apples with her feet wearing her knickerbockers, you must come and see her (Nicosia)."]
['Check out the really good pub that I like (Czech Republic) but be pragmatic and keep out of arguments (Prague).']
['The denim he wore marked (Denmark) him out as a farmer, who was coping with getting all the hay gone (Copenhagen) from the field into the barn.']
['Estimate the number of stones (Estonia) and admire his talent (Tallinn).']
['Fins were all around me as I floated away from the land (Finland) and I held on to the sink (Helsinki).']
['Frogs that dance (France) are sold as souvenirs. They are made out of plaster of paris (Paris).']
["Germs, especially when there are many (Germany) need to be exterminated. That's why Beethoven burnt his violin (Berlin)."]
["Get grease (Greece), put a thin (Athens) layer on a pole and you won't get up it."]
["I'm hungry (Hungary) said the Buddha and so he kept pestering (Budapest) his chef to cook him something."]
['The ice land (Iceland) was built using a rake by a vicar (Reykjavik).']
['The iron man was in a land (Ireland) where everyone had a double in tow (Dublin).']
["It didn't tally (Italy) when they did a survey of wellington boots, so they had to roam (Rome) the country to count them all again."]
['The cosmos over (Kosovo) his head was shaped like a priest playing the concertina (Pristina).']
['His Latin veers (Latvia) from good to bad, but he always looks quite regal (Riga).']
['After he licked a ten-stone man – or was he nine? (Liechtenstein) – the alien decided to invade and loot (Vaduz).']
['You lit your anus (Lithuania) to scare off the villain who was near us (Vilnius).']
['The two people were eating luxury burgers (Luxembourg) and playing snap at the same time.']
['The malt had a (Malta) lovely holiday – it sent the whole valley, where it came from, a letter (Valletta) to say what a great time it was having on holiday.']
['He mulled over (Moldova) his losses and decided there would be no more visits to the casino now (Chisinau).']

['Note: When the main characters of an image are playing snap, this means that the capital city has the same name as the country.', 'If you have a monocle\xa0 then you would be in good company (Monaco) in this villa (Monaco-Ville) – they love playing snap.']
['She had a monster ego (Montenegro) considering she was a podgy gorilla eating pizza (Podgorica).']
['The lion never lands (Netherlands) well but the hamster can (Amsterdam).']
["The massive doner (Macedonia) kebab was the scorpion's (Skopje) favourite food."]
['North was this way (Norway), but the wizard of Oz slowed (Oslo) them down.']
['Polo was the national sport in this land (Poland) but it became dangerous when they started using war saws (Warsaw) instead of polo sticks.']
['The port drunk by this girl (Portugal) was the reason why she had a lisp and her bonnet (Lisbon) was sliding off her head.']
['She was a roman maniac (Romania), she loved everything roman. In fact she never gave any book on Romans a rest (Bucharest) until she finished it.']
['She rushed in and fed (Russian Federation) moss to the cow (Moscow).']

definition: San Marino's capital is San Marino
mnemonic: ['Sandwiched in a marina (San Marino), they had no choice but to play snap (the same).']
["They will serve beer (Serbia) if the bell that's grey is rung (Belgrade)."]
['You can slowly vacuum (Slovakia) the brat till she is laughing (Bratislava).']
['He was so slovenly (Slovenia) that his mum just went loopy and smashed his room up with a hammer (Ljubljana).']
["His pain (Spain) was so obvious but that didn't bother the mad Riddler (Madrid)."]
['The swedes weighed ten tons (Sweden); the problem was how to get this stock home (Stockholm).']
['The pilot switched her landing (Switzerland) from the runway that was burning (Bern).']
['All the turkeys (Turkey) had anchors around (Ankara) their ankles.']
['You have to use a crane (Ukraine) when the giant key is heaved (Kyiv) into the air.']
['The united Kings (United Kingdom) all had long johns on (London).']

mnemonic: ['What a pair of fatties the cans (Vatican) were ; they just sat around playing snap.']
